title: Hurray for Hrant (and Spatium #4)
content:
I just got a copy of the newest edition of _Spatium,_ a German magazine on typography produced by the Typosition Studio in Offenbach. The star article in the issue is by Hrant, on the Latinization of Non-Latin scripts and typefaces   
   
Snipits about Spatium and Hrant's article have been heard on typophile before, but I think that it is now time for everyone to place their orders for the magazine, as it has finally arrived (it was presented publicly for the first time today, in Offenbach, of course). This issue, unlike the previous three, is printed in both German and English.   
   
Spatium Magazine   
 [http://www.spatium-newsletter.de/index.php](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518052815/http:/www.spatium-newsletter.de/index.php)   
   
Typosition   
 [http://www.typosition.de/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518052815/http:/www.typosition.de/)   
   
   
(There is also a tiny contribution on page 49 from TypeOff., the HfG Offenbach's Type Design Collective. [http://www.typeoff.de](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518052815/http:/www.typeoff.de/))
author: dan_reynolds

Well, I'd like people to actually buy the issue, so I won't put up a full PDF of it (at least not for a while), but the point of the essay is to explain what Latinization is and where it comes from (and how ancient it is), show exactly what can be good but what is usually bad about it, and conclude with a technical elaboration of how to "channel" it positively in making a multi-script typeface system.

Today's German lesson will teach all of you how to order your copies of Spatium quickly and easily�   
   
 ![spatium screen shot](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518052815im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/30/47393.jpg)   
   
First, go to [http://www.spatium-newsletter.de/index.php](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518052815/http:/www.spatium-newsletter.de/index.php)   
and click the word "Bestellung" in the top nav menu. "Bestellung" means "order"   
   
The current magazine issue is called "Gruppe 11," which means "Group 11." Issue number 2, as well as two t-shirts are also available for purchase. These are really chic, especially the "girly" shirts.   
   
If you just want a copy of the magazine, type a 1 under the "Anzahl" slot to the left of "Magazine Gruppe 11" (under the red "Bestellen"). "Anzahl" means "number," so don't type 2 unless you want two copies�   
   
Then type in your mailing address. "Stra�e/Nr:" means "Street and House Number." The Germans type things in that order (Geisbergstra�e 3), but you can ignore their silly conventions and type in you address the good old american way, as I've done here. "PLZ/Ort" means "Zip Code and Place." "Land" means "Country."   
   
Clicking the "Artikel bestellen" button (which means "order item") will lead to some other magical page, I imagine� I've never ordered anything online from Spatium before, so I don't know what happens next, but it is probably self expanatory. If you get sad because this form is just too confusing, you can e-mail Peter directly by clicking on the "Kontakt" (which means "contact") button in the upper right-hand corner of the screen.
